entry.summary: ...WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM AKDT THURSDAY... * WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations up to 8 inches. * WHERE...Northeastern Brooks Range above 4000 feet. * WHEN...Until 4 PM AKDT Thursday.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 06 at 2:45PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water on the Tanana River Continues This Week... The Tanana River continues to fall slowly this week. Rain from Tuesday night through Thursday will cause water levels to fluctuate slightly, but the risk of flooding is over. People recreating or hunting on the Tanana River should be aware that many gravel bars will be covered with water, debris will be in the
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Interior; Deltana and Tanana Flats; Middle Tanana Valley; Upper Tanana Valley and the Fortymile Country

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 06 at 2:45PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow Above 3000 Feet In The Alaska Range Through Thursday... In the Western Alaska Range including the Denali area, expect storm total snowfall of 6 inches above 3000 ft by the time the snow ends this evening. Eielson Visitor Center at 3600 ft had 4 inches of snow as of noon Wednesday. In the Isabell Pass area, expect 4 to 6 inches of snow above 3000

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 06 at 2:45PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High River Levels This Week... High river levels will continue this week on the Kobuk and Noatak Rivers, and rivers on the Seward Peninsula. Heavy rain that fell Tuesday night through Wednesday night is causing the high water. No flooding is expected at this time, but people camping and boating along rivers should be alert for rising water and
entry.cap:areaDesc: Baldwin Peninsula and Selawik Valley; Lower Kobuk and Noatak Valleys; Northern and Interior Seward Peninsula; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Upper Kobuk and Noatak Valleys

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 06 at 2:17PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Heavy Precipitation Will Impact the Outer Coast Through The Weekend... A low pressure system and associated front over the Gulf of Alaska will steer a plume of subtropical moisture over the eastern Gulf and Southeast Alaska late this week and into the weekend. Greatest storm totals will occur in areas north of Cross Sound
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Yakutat; Glacier Bay

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 06 at 2:17PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Ozone Action Day... entry.summary: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 1 AM CDT THURSDAY THROUGH THURSDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Life threatening waves of 3 to 4 feet and dangerous currents are expected. * WHERE...Racine County. * WHEN...From 1 AM CDT Thursday through Thursday evening.
